newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian ferry to challenge Eurotunnel.
newsitem.headline: Belgian ferry to challenge Eurotunnel.

text.p: Eurotunnel SA/Plc faces a new competitor from Saturday when Belgium's loss-making state ferry company RTM-RMT is reborn as Holyman-Sally Ferries.

The new company, which is owned by Australia's Holyman Ltd and Finland's Oy Silja Line AB, aims to cut the journey time on the Ostend-Ramsgate crossing to around 100 minutes from over four hours at present by employing two high-speed ferries in place of RMT-RTM's fleet of four conventional vessels.
Belgium's government invited the two private companies to take over the RTM-RMT operation last year after it had run up accumulated debts in excess of 12 billion Belgian francs ($380 million).

Officially, the route will continue to be run by the RTM-RMT and Holyman Sally on a pool basis until 1999. The government has said it expects RTM-RMT to lose a further 3.5 billion francs in 1997 and 1998.
The new high-speed service begins at 1200 local (1100 GMT) from Ostend on Saturday March 1. The company will initially offer five crossings a day, a spokesman for the company told Reuters.
This will likely rise to seven in the summer months of July and August.

Each ferry can carry 700 people and 170 cars, but no freight trucks. Passenger tickets would initially be priced at 499 Belgian francs for a day trip, or 1,950 francs for a five-day return including train connection to London.
A five day return for a car with two passengers will be 2,400 Belgian francs.
Le Shuttle was on Friday quoting 6,200 Belgian francs for a period return for a car and its passengers.
Eurostar the passenger train service that uses Eurotunnel charges around 3,000 francs for a day return or 5,200 francs for a normal return ticket.
